sentences_tone.text: AMD: The Coming Technology War With Nvidia - Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. (NYSE:AMD) | Seeking AlphaSign in / Join NowGO»Market NewsStock IdeasDividendsMarket OutlookInvesting StrategyETFs & FundsEarningsPROLong IdeasShort IdeasCramer's PicksIPOsQuick PicksSectorsEditor's PicksAMD: The Coming Technology War With NvidiaNov.11.16 | About: Advanced Micro (AMD) The Structure Of Price Follow Hedge fund manager, long/short equity, portfolio strategy, goldSend MessageSummaryAMD has in probability pressured NVIDIA to move up their launch of Volta, making them switch to 16nm FinFET manufacture from the originally intended 10nm FinFET.By developing a mega chip AMD could achieve vertical product integration, a market disruptive innovation gaining the company significant competitive advantage.To keep pace, NVIDIA may be modifying streaming processor function for Volta to achieve "substantial performance-per-watt gains over Pascal".AMD holds 29.9% of the add-in graphics boards market to NVIDIA's 70.1%, but this and market for integrated GPUs is in linear decline, a shrinking battlefield.AMD may have technology edge, but greater GPU market focus and far greater cash resources lend NVIDIA opposing advantages in Vega/Volta face off.

Click to enlarge
The quickest way of ending a war is to lose it.

-- George Orwell
As in war and in boxing, so it is in business.

The maxim "Be first!" emphasizes the importance of being the lead protagonist to the fray, the one to establish the nature of the juxtaposition, a base from which to develop, an identity in the fight; of seeking to define the conflict in one's own terms, denying that opportunity to the opponent; of seizing the initiative; of forcing the opponent to be on the defensive, to play catch up.

GPU Battleground: Vega Versus Volta In this light, the 2017 battleground for the technology war between Advanced Micro Devices Inc (NYSE:AMD) and NVIDIA Corp (NASDAQ:NVDA) is the competition between AMD's next generation GPU Vega and NVIDIA's Volta GPU.
AMD may have already achieved initial advantage.

First announced years ago, with roll out often deferred and most recently scheduled for 2018, industry sources now consider it possible that NVIDIA's Volta launch has been moved up to May, 2017, under pressure of the imminent roll out of Vega by AMD.
NVIDIA has delayed its next annual GPU Technology Conference, usually held in March, to May 2017, possibly to accommodate announcement of Volta's launch at that time.

This would also explain the many recent iterations of Pascal cards through GTX 1080 to 1070, GTX 1060, and the $1,200 GTX Titan X, as the company seeks to maximize monetization of the present architecture before its retirement.

Pressure Of Time And Competition Under pressure of competition from AMD and to achieve earlier launch, it is thought NVIDIA have been forced to make design and manufacturing changes to Volta, bringing to mind the generals' adage that no battle plan survives contact with the enemy.

Volta was originally slated to be NVIDIA's first 10nm FinFET architecture, but that manufacturing process is not yet sufficiently advanced to produce highly complex silicon for a large GPU on the time scale being dictated by AMD.
Consequently NVIDIA was obliged to abandon 10nm FinFET for Volta and revert to 16nm FinFET manufacture as used in Pascal.
AMD's Vega gains a modest technical advantage here by utilizing 14nm FinFET manufacture, and a big psychological advantage in having forced NVIDIA's hand and placed them on the defensive.
Vega To Combine With Zen AMD achieved this by announcing that Vega will start shipping in 1H17.
Vega targets virtual reality, gaming, and desktop applications which require high performance GPUs.
It will carry next gen HBM2 (high bandwidth memory) in stacked form, offering throughput of up to 256GBps.
It will also offer AMD's current performance enhancements for modern graphics APIs like DirectX 12 and Vulkan.

Vega GPUs will provide significant performance and power efficiency improvements compared to AMD's Polaris -- Mark Papermaster, AMD chief technology officer
AMD foresees that Vega will combine with their Zen CPU, scheduled for production in 1H17, a combination which potentially endows significant advantages of price and performance.
The goal for Zen, as stated by AMD, is "to bring a 40% generational improvement in instructions per clock within the power requirements of previous gen".
Zen will be scalable to meet many uses across embedded systems, fanless 2-in-1s, data centers and high performance computing.
Zen chips for enterprise class servers are projected for 2Q17.

Mega Chip Could Redefine Market Importantly, AMD is doing development work on a mega chip combining Zen with what may be a Vega-based GPU for use in servers and high performance computers (see Seeking Alpha "How AMD May Redefine The CPU And GPU Markets In Its Favor").
This is seizing the initiative indeed.
Vertical technology integration is potentially an area of high competitive advantage for AMD as NVIDIA does not have and is not scheduled to develop a CPU comparable to Zen.
NVIDIA have had to combine their GPUs with either International Business Machines Corp (NYSE:IBM) or AMD CPUs to achieve supercomputer performance.
Therefore vertical integration would be a market disruptive innovation to AMD's great benefit, likely handing them both performance and pricing advantage over NVIDIA's hybrid alternatives.
An assessment of the competition for AMD's Vega indicates that Volta, as described by NVIDIA, is bringing "substantial performance-per-watt gains over Pascal", the architecture which preceded Volta.

It is believed this has been achieved by modifying the streaming processor function, as NVIDIA did in the Maxwell upgrade from prior generation Kepler, while it stayed relatively similar in the subsequent upgrade from Maxwell to Pascal.
Full Integration Of Stacked Memory Volta also employs full integration of stacked memory as previously used by NVIDIA in its Pascal architecture Tesla core for data centers.
It is expected that Volta will address the issue of Pascal's lack of sparkling performance in modern APIs.

The most recently available Jon Peddie Research market share data for add-in graphics boards based on present architecture is for Q2 of 2016 and shows AMD shipping 2.82 million units to NVIDIA's 6.61 million, by projection giving AMD a 29.9% market share to NVIDIA's 70.1%.

Of real concern to AMD and NVIDIA, however, must be the fact that both the market for add-in boards and that for integrated GPUs as reflected in worldwide desktop pc shipments are in linear decline, and pc shipment volume is projected to fall still further.
Markets Shrinking For Combatants Shipment volume of add-in boards has declined 24% since Q4 2014, while volume of pc shipments has declined 23.6% since Q4 2014.
The coming technology war then will be fought upon territory which is shrinking beneath the combatants' feet.

Further, a developing presence in the deep learning and AI (artificial intelligence) graphics segments is Intel Corp (NASDAQ:INTC) as they seek to acquire start ups in this space, a cheaper and quicker way of achieving market share than doing their own R&D and product development.
Both AMD and NVIDIA will need to heed this emerging competitive threat.
There is a difference of corporate focus at play which should be borne in mind when considering AMD's coming technology war.
NVIDIA is fully concentrated on GPU architecture, while AMD's areas of specialization stretch across server and pc processors, semi-custom SoCs (system-on-chips), and GPUs.

This focal difference becomes all the more salient when the relative size of the companies' resources available for their conflict in the GPU space is considered, as is discussed later in this article.
Interrelationship Of Price And Performance Two interrelated dimensions of their market competition will be performance and price.

If we on the basis of the limited information about Vega and Volta yet available conjecture a rough approximation of performance and power draw across both products, it may be assumed that AMD will be eager to compete on price, just as it is anticipated that Zen will compete on price when taking on Intel's Broadwell chip, and as AMD has previously done in the graphics card segment in its fight with NVIDIA for market share.
A price war would play into AMD's value pricing reputation and culture, though it would not be the most satisfactory outcome for its balance sheet.
The corporate resources of each company will naturally determine their relative abilities to wage technology war against each other in the 2017 GPU marketplace.
Key aspects of the resources each may bring to bear in the conflict are highlighted below.
In its recent debt restructuring, AMD reduced its interest load and pushed a major portion back to 2026.
Now no term debt falls due before 2019, improving its financial expenditure abilities for the next two years.
Annual interest savings amount to approximately $55 million, clawing back cash flow which previously went to debt servicing.
The restructuring also produced $162 million in generated cash, enabling AMD to purchase more silicon wafer from GlobalFoundries to boost production output if it so chooses.
Positive Free Cash Flow AMD experienced negative free cash flow in all but two of the last seven quarters resulting from net loss and high interest payments.
In 3Q16, though, the company showed positive free cash flow of $20 million and anticipates that it will remain positive in 4Q16.
NVIDIA by contrast has over the last five quarters enjoyed operating cash flow ranging from $160 million to above $500 million.
The projection for 3Q17 is cash flow approximating $300 million.
NVIDIA's net cash position is $4.4 billion, far greater than that of AMD which has a net debt position of approximately $400 million.
Conclusions The 2017 technology war AMD will fight against NVIDIA will be on the battlefield of the GPU market through their Vega and Volta next generation architectures.

With little precise technical information on performance or power draw for either product yet available, it is probable in the event of comparable performance that AMD would seek to compete on price as this has been their modus operandi of record.

The war may then turn out to be more one of price and financial resources than of technology
From AMD investors' standpoint, price competition may aid AMD in securing greater market share but would reduce their profit margin, prove disadvantageous to their balance sheet, and possibly be deleterious of their share price.
The latter consideration is of particular significance because AMD's share price has already entered a substantial structural downturn (See Seeking Alpha "AMD: Time To Short A Major Retracement").
As this author has a long term positive view of AMD stock, this pullback may be viewed as an opportunity to buy at its nadir.
With limited financial resources compared to NVIDIA, AMD's constitutional ability to sustain price competition over an extended period is markedly lower than that of NVIDIA.
AMD must hope therefore that Vega has clear performance advantages over Volta to an extent great enough to obviate the need for a price war.
Pressures of time and competition from AMD have likely already forced NVIDIA to modify their design, production plans and launch date for Volta, which may well be announced in May 2017.
This fact gives AMD initial advantage through hurrying its opponent and forcing modification of its product.

The markets for add-in graphics boards and integrated GPUs in which the companies compete are both in linear decline, requiring AMD and NVIDIA to urgently consider ways in which existing markets may be expanded and new markets developed in order to counteract this downward trend which will ultimately inure to both companies' detriment.
This factor is all the more telling when the developing threat from Intel in the deep learning and AI segments is taken into account.

AMD has improved its balance sheet with the recent debt restructuring it has undertaken, and the company may hold the technology edge, especially with regard to the disruptive innovation which may flow from the introduction of a mega chip.
They will need these factors to combat the advantage of greater GPU market focus and far greater cash resources possessed by NVIDIA in their efforts to win the coming 2017 technology war.
